articles.title: Outdoor notes — Aug. 30
articles.summary: Migratory game bird hunting seasons open Sept. 1. The first dove season runs through Oct. 18 from noon to sunset. The second dove season is Oct. 25-Nov. 28, and the third dove season from Dec. 20-Jan. 9, 2026. The early resident Canada goose season runs Sept 1-15 in the Eastern zone and Sept.1-25 in the Western zone.

articles.title: The hidden health crisis: How climate change is affecting human well-being
articles.author: Our Reporter
articles.summary: According to WHO, climate change is the single biggest health threat facing humanity. It affects human health in many direct and indirect ways. Heat-related illnesses are on the rise due to rising temperatures. Climate change is also facilitating the spread of vector-borne diseases like malaria, dengue fever, and Zika virus. The most vulnerable populations are disproportionately affected by climate-related health impacts. Government, international organizations and individuals need to work together to address this growing health crisis.

articles.title: Drivers urged to consider repainting their cars for key reason
articles.author: Carrington Walker
articles.summary: Scientists from the University of Lisbon have advised UK drivers to change the colour of their car to reduce the urban heat island effect. Dark-coloured vehicles release more heat than lighter ones. A black car raised nearby air temperatures by up to 3.8°C, while a white car had a smaller effect.

articles.title: Sindh govt cancels leaves of Agri Dept officers
articles.author: Recorder Report
articles.summary: Sindh government cancels leaves of Agriculture Department officers to deal with potential flood situation. Rain emergency cell established in the office of the Director General Agriculture in Hyderabad. Emergency centers established up to the tappa level in all districts of the province. Focal Persons appointed in 30 districts. 24/7 rain emergency control room activated in the Agriculture Extension Wing, Hyderabad, supervised by the Director of Agriculture Extension, Sindh. A helpline number, 0311-1164611, issued for the convenience of farmers.

articles.title: Robyn Williams shares his favourite stories from 50 years of the Science Show
articles.author: Jacinta Bowler
articles.summary: Fifty years ago today, Robyn Williams recorded the first episode of ABC Radio National's Science Show at the 13th Pacific Science Congress in Vancouver, Canada. The first episode featured scientists concerned about the nuclear arms race, the rate of animal extinction, and the impact of burning fossil fuels and climate change. The Science Show has been a beacon for the Australian science community.

articles.title: Conned and Lied to by our leaders: Australia's Opportunity for Global Leadership Rejecting Globalist Capture — Reclaiming National Sovereignty!
articles.author: Ian Brighthope
articles.summary: Malcolm Robert is proud to be a member of Aussies for Better Government. He detests politicians, but loves and admires humans. He worked for nine years researching climate science. He held people accountable for 18 years in the senate and before the senate. He also researched the corruption of climate science leading to the UN.

articles.title: PM unveils plan to devise joint water strategy
articles.author: Dawn
articles.summary: Army chief visits flood-hit areas. He calls climate change a national issue. Iranian president offers condolences and assistance. Sikh: "Climate change is a reality, and only through effective preparedness can the damages of natural disasters be minimised".

articles.title: Landsat 9 Sees Buccaneer Archipelago
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: The Operational Land Imager on Landsat 9 captured the image of Buccaneer Archipelago on June 11, 2025. The scene encapsulates the striking interactions between land and water in the area where King Sound opens to the Indian Ocean. The powerful tidal currents stir up sediment in shallow areas, producing the beautiful turquoise swirls.

articles.title: Microalgae Key to Carbon Absorption in Southern Ocean
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Algal blooms in the Southern Ocean 14,000 years ago helped to reduce the global carbon dioxide content of the atmosphere. The current decline in sea ice in this region poses a serious threat to these algae. Phaeocystis is particularly endangered in Antarctica because of sea ice loss.

articles.title: Hunters reminded of hunt boundary change for Canada goose in southeast Idaho (Idaho Department of Fish and Game)
articles.author: Public Technologies
articles.summary: Hunters should take note of the hunt boundary changes in Areas 3 and 4 in southeast Idaho this fall and how that may impact the timing of their hunting fun. Area 4 in the area is the hunting area for Canada geese in the state of Idaho.

articles.title: A costly gamble
articles.author: Ebadat Ur Rehman Babar
articles.summary: Khyber Pakhtunkhwa (KP) has endured two climate catastrophes in three years. The province has earmarked billions for mitigation and adaptation in its 2023-24 budget. However, the funding is poorly tracked and scattered across departments. KP needs to adopt climate budget tagging across departments and take lessons from the federal government's recent reforms.

articles.title: EDITORIAL: Wildfire figures show a shifting trend
articles.author: Black Press
articles.summary: Since the beginning of April, wildfires destroyed more than 730,000 hectares of forest land in British Columbia. Wildfires destroyed close to 2.9 million hectares in the province in 2023. Four of the worst wildfire seasons in the past decade have been within the last decade.

articles.title: Weather By The Numbers
articles.author: Jim Kosek
articles.summary: Abadan, Iran has the hottest weather today with 118 degrees. Dome C on the eastern plateau of Antarctica dipped to negative 86 degrees. The coldest place in Michigan was Big Bay, MI and Covington, MI where it was as cold as 27 degrees this morning.

articles.title: Climate Negligence
articles.summary: The recent flood in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa (KP) has claimed 365 lives, injured hundreds and left thousands homeless. Pakistan is among the most climate-vulnerable countries globally. The government reduced disaster risk reduction funding instead of increasing it. The Environment Division's budget was slashed from 3.78 billion last year to 3.06 billion this year.

articles.title: A Nation Under Water
articles.summary: The recent floods in Pakistan have devastated various regions of the country. The people of Swat and other affected regions have shown exceptional resilience. However, such resilience should not substitute for systemic preparedness. Pakistan needs to invest in adaptive infrastructure, construction of embankments, modernised river management systems and early warning mechanisms.

articles.title: Climate change: What will happen to legal status of 'sinking' nations when their land is gone?
articles.author: The Conversation
articles.summary: Small island nations such as Tuvalu, Kiribati, the Maldives and Marshall Islands are particularly vulnerable to climate change. The future status of these nations as states matters a lot. The loss of statehood could strip these nations of control over valuable natural resources and even cost them their place in international organisations such as the UN.

articles.title: UK weather maps pinpoint where exactly the 30C September Indian Summer peak will be
articles.author: The Mirror
articles.summary: Temperatures in the UK are soon going to rise again. Forecasters predict an Indian Summer is likely to occur next month. In some places the temperature could reach 30C in some places, which is hotter than normal for this time of the year.

articles.title: Migration of geese fly over the fertile fields of Watsonville
articles.author: Santa Cruz Sentinel
articles.summary: A formation of Canada geese fly over field workers bringing in the bounty of the Pajaro Valley in a field along San Andreas Road in California's San Andreas Valley.       i.e. the geese are flying over the field.

articles.title: Rising sea levels should be a local priority
articles.summary: States on the Atlantic, Pacific and Gulf coasts are doing whatever they can to prepare shoreline communities for rising seas. Glynn County officials are addressing flood issues during king tides along the F.J. Torras Causeway. Both the city and county are working on controlling street and residential flooding during periods of heavy rain.

articles.title: Shanghai reports record 25th consecutive day of high temperatures
articles.author: Source: Xinhua
articles.summary: Shanghai has experienced its 25th consecutive day of temperatures above 35 degrees Celsius on Saturday, breaking a nearly century-old record for the longest continuous stretch of high temperatures in the city's history. The previous record of 24 consecutive high-temperature days was set in 1926, when scorching heat persisted from July 22 to August 14. This year's prolonged heat wave has dealt Shanghai a total of 44 high temperature days so far. The August heat has been particularly intense, with 26 high temperatures days in the last 30 days.

articles.title: Shanghai breaks 99-year record of 25 straight days with temperatures above 35°C
articles.author: Anadolu staff
articles.summary: Shanghai has experienced 25 consecutive days with temperatures above 35 degrees Celsius (95 degrees Fahrenheit) from August 6 to 30. The previous record was 24 consecutive days set in 1926. In July, China issued high heat warnings for 754 provinces, cities, and counties.

articles.title: Heat warning in effect for central Manitoba
articles.author: CTV
articles.summary: Environment and Climate Change Canada is concerned about climate change. It's concerned about the effects of climate change on the environment and climate change change on people's lives. Its main focus is on people and their livelihoods. It is also concerned about people's well-being.

articles.title: Surge in numbers emigrating to Australia
articles.author: The Irish Times
articles.summary: More than 65,000 people left Ireland in the 12 months to April. 13,500 people left to go to Australia, an increase of 27% year on year and 187% on the year before.    - CSO's figures were much more common years ago.

articles.title: Ken Paxton's attack on investors is climate change denial, not conservatism
articles.author: Fox News
articles.summary: In 2024, the United States endured 27 hurricane-force storms. The economic toll from the storms is increasing every year and the flooding is more severe each year. The storms are becoming stronger and more destructive each year, especially in the southern states. The families prepare and pray for the storms.

articles.title: Strengthen climate policy implementation in Upper West
articles.author: Modern Ghana
articles.summary: The She Leads Social Movement in the Upper West Region has called on the Regional Coordinating Council (RCC) to intensify climate policy implementation in order to secure a just and sustainable future. The RCC has not yet responded to the call.

articles.author: Beatrice Daily Sun
articles.summary: A change in climate policy by the Trump administration threatens to change everything on earth, from the fast-warming planet itself to all the life on it, writes Julian Zelizer. He is concerned about the future of the planet and all life on earth.

articles.title: Delhi set to record coolest August in 13 years: IMD data
articles.author: Hindustan Times
articles.summary: The Capital is on course to record its coolest August in the last 13 years since 2012. The average maximum temperature till Saturday is 33.2°C, while the average maximum in August 2012 was 33.1°C. There will be some spells of light to light rain with thundershowers on Sunday.
